comments.commentBody:
Opps...Just read the last sentence
of Step 3! Never mind!

Sure "our country" could do all those things. Or we could look at a country like Sweden that has all those government-mandated programs. Then it becomes clear why socialism - and its very high taxes, higher unemployment, more business failures, fewer startups, and a dearth of innovation - would not be a step forward for anyone that wants to work for a living.

Completely agree.

Only a few characters really evolve in anyway, mostly Rick and Carol, although Carol plateaued with look at the flowers. (Yes Morgan has swung to two sides of crazy, but that's it).

Are we really supposed to accept the 50 shades of Rick, from small town cop to Rictator to farmer to neck biter to sobbing over an Alexandrian cracking jokes on the deathbed? Will the real Rick, please stand up.

This show is going the way of LOST in the middle seasons when the cast became cumbersome and too much time was spent on minor or new characters, depriving the show of the emotional connection the audience had built with the core characters.  We've hardly seen Daryl at all; who cares if Abe is attracted to Sasha; the Alexandrians are one note - unbelievably stupid; ... I could go in.  Writers, get back to the vote group more!
That old saying, children should be seen and heard , was never so true. Btw, I too expected more...
Totally disagree with you Clarice - rivals seasons 1 and 4 as the best Homeland season.

I agree completely, APB. Love this season. I almost wish Allison could go on to be a kind of super villain they pursue across Europe next season. Carrie, Saul, and Quinn are best as spies, and I like the German spies, too -- more of them!

And I think Quinn lives -- he's going to be the one who can convince Dar of Allison's guilt.
I agree.  It's hard to believe hardened CIA guys would fall for that, especially Carrie.   She knows the truth.

I loved tonight's edge-of-your-seat episode.  It felt like the Homeland I know and love is finally back on track with characters behaving in the ways we love and are accustomed to.  Can't believe that someone as sharp and ruthless as Dar Adal would fall for Allison's "hail mary" at the end - no way Carrie buys it.  Women aren't so easily played by an attractive woman as men!!  This episode made me realize what has been lacking this season is our favorite core characters working toward a common plot goal - it's the interactions between these characters (Quinn, Carrie, Saul, Dar) and the world they inhabit that is so compelling about the show.
Probably one of the best episodes all season. They can't really believe Allison's story though she sounds quite convincing. Hell of a kicker. Can't wait for next week.
yes Dar was unbelievably naive in this scene.
Allison herself explained this to Dar, whom she may or may not have convinced: she had been told that her station had been compromised, so she couldn't trust anyone to help her bring Ivan in.

If Allison was bringing Ivan in for the Americans then why was she playing cat and mouse with the American and German agents who were following her?  Wouldn't she have brought a couple of agents as her backups?  And would she really have gone to Ivan's hideout instead of telling him to leave it right away?  If I were Dar these are questions I would ask.  Oh and why didn't Dar give her the same lie detector test they are always giving Saul?   There are so many questions and Allison won't be able to answer them all.

I have trouble with the conceit of Carrie sabotaging Saul's candidacy to head the CIA; if Saul's Lear, she's definitely Cordelia. Not so much trouble disbelieving that Allison has been working Ivan as her agent; something I suspect nobody on the CIA side will bite on. But I do have the sneaking feeling she may yet wrangle a deal placing her on the beach with that drink.
What was the point of Alison asking a waitress how much she earned?
I would have grabbed Whitney's phone and kept it. She's obnoxious.

Nobody has commented on the depiction of how intrusive and obnoxious smartphones can be/are.  The scene of Whitney repeatedly snapping photos of Helen and creating an online dating profile for her seemed to illustrate this, as did Noah's publicity agent Eden glued to her phone throughout the Thanksgiving dinner.  Also, when Noah gets into the bar fight, it is immediately captured by several on-lookers with their cell phone cameras and posted online.  What a sad world this is becoming.
Helen's mother makes me cringe.  What a horror!  I was glad when Helen kicked her out and saw through her manipulation.
This occurred to me as well.

and Elke

Did the puzzle online (instead of printing it out ). Discovered stars come in two colours-- : blue and (yea) gold . Guess I had the MIDAS TOUCH today.

Finally inserted an apostrophe in the proper place (MID A'S TOUCH )and MAGIC happened.
Liked seeing POLLY crossing PAULA (ABDUL). The former is a diminutive of the latter.
Is PRESLEY considered an OLDIE?
LHASA APSOS sure need a lot of GROOMing for SHOW preparation.
The tape of the "SPEAKing" dog is a RIOT.
Always amazed at the COOL tricks constructors can create.

Hi Jason! Yes, I saw the Descent 2 theory... Very interesting! I thought perhaps I had missed something. This episode was so jam-packed with simultaneous breakdowns (in all senses of the word) and all during a giant storm, it is too much like the climax of a suspense novel, I'm still on board 100% that this is straight from a novel. I did read an article somewhere by the creator of the show saying that they would definitely reveal the killer this season and that they thought they had enough material to go for another season. But I'm with you.... They are running out of time. Given the nature of the writing so far, I eagerly anticipate what other surprises they have in store for us!

Despite what you see on the variety of Atlanta based reality shows on Bravo, which would certainly lead you to believe otherwise, Atlanta is not like this either. Seven years in NYC, however, and I can totally see it.

@Larry... In some of the comments last week there was discussion of a second baby who was around at the point of the trial.... They said that Alison referred to the nursery as "his" room and that the baby at the trial was female (Joanie). We now see that Alison is very pregnant at the second trial so I guess there is a second baby after all!!?

Holy smokes, that was intense. Full of symbolism and my head is spinning. So, it is Coles baby. It is a girl child, there is no second baby as suggested. Cole does appear to know if this baby (from preview for episode 10). I now believe the most honorable person on the show is Max, which doesn't say much for humanity. Holy ****, Noah almost had a threesome with his daughter!

It's a wonderful idea but did you look at the picture of that yellow "home" he lived in? The article said it's only reachable by driving 'miles' of mountain roads in the middle of nowhere. It's a shack. And it looks creepy as hell. I doubt that communities in such areas have the resources to employ enough social workers to cover their their territory and I doubt you would find many people signing up for the job. I remember hearing that law enforcement itself is dwindling quite a bit outside of the main metropolitan areas of the country. Rural and remote communities can't afford to pay for full-time police so towns now share.
To me the more promising issue relates to technology: when you have someone who has a history of complaints filed against him for animal cruelty, domestic abuse, AND being a peeping tom with a restraining order as a result, it seems to me that at this point in our technological world law enforcement should have had some flags up on this guy wherever he registers to vote or receive his tax return. There's nothing wrong with local police being alerted to the new guy in town having a history of brushes with the law. That's who should be checking up on him every once in awhile.

@Brad. Maybe because I have the experience of my mother doing those things for me all through college ( and law school) and yet I grew up to be a competent capable adult who managed totally in every way on my own once I moved out after finishing my education. My mother also had parents who took care of things for her til she moved out after college. Heck my grandmothers parents were the same. She'd never cooked washed a dish she reported til she moved out of her parents home to marry. She managed a lovely home once she did.

I personally do for my kids the things I like and enjoy. Laundry, organizing etc... And make them do those I don't: making lunches since age 7 for example.
Can you use canned artichokes if frozen are not readily available?

The ones who have domestic abuse/cruelty to animal/peeping Tom complaints filed against them would be a good start. I'd vote for that law.  In Canada you have to prove your gun owner-worthiness over several years and TESTS (what a concept) plus have two law-abiding gun owners vouch for you.  If you ever use your gun illegally they lose their licenses too. It's a system of high accountability and sanity. And they don't seem to have this recurring problem of mass shootings by deranged, alienated men.  At all.  Honestly, I thought Sandy Hook would do it.  If the mass murder of kindergarteners didn't shift this issue, I don't think anything will.
I always reduce the amount of water by half a cup and add that amount of milk.  Also add a little butter.  To my tsdte it is yum!

Lee H. stated much the same further down where I responded in some minor detail.   I won't repeat but just state that looking at all the electricity grids of the world you have it wrong.  Nuclear power plants are planned in considerable numbers by many.

He is lucky he was not in college where it is mandated that the girl be believed and the male is guilty until proven innocent.
By the way AJ he did it since that type of behavior is consistent with Koby's stellar personality. A classic man/child with too much fame and money.
Not 'is' - 'was'.  Kobe's been an average player for a while and now's he's mediocre.

Definitely, top of the front page news!

Thanks to the Times for recognizing what's important.
I second that...what a lousy human being.

Sex criminals unite?  Please, no position with any kind of "accountability", as clearly absent here would suit Keh or his ilk.   Maybe collecting shopping carts or as greeters at Walmart would be more appropriate.

Why is this inappropriate? Being charged with sexual assault is not the norm, and it was a huge part of the man's public persona in the minds of many (I'd wager to say, in about 51% of the population).
Why not add it? It was an integral part of his career's timeline.

It is entirely inappropriate to drop in as a one-liner in the middle of an article about Kobe Bryant's basketball career the following: "In 2003, he was accused of sexual assault in Colorado. He pleaded not guilty, and the charges were eventually dropped."

Both Andrew Keh and his editor might be better served working for a supermarket checkstand tabloid.
